sen.j: 桜井 勉（さくらい つとむ、1843年10月6日（天保14年9月13日 (旧暦)） - 1931年（昭和6年）10月12日）は、明治時代の行政官。
sen.e: Tsutomu SAKURAI (October 6, 1843-October 12, 1931) was an administrative official in the Meiji period.
Tsutomu SAKURAI (October 6, 1843 - October 12, 1931) was an administrative official in the Meiji period.

sen.j: 日本の天気予報の創始者とされる。
sen.e: He is said to be the founder of weather forecast in Japan.

sen.j: 出石藩の儒官・桜井石門の長男として出石町伊木（現兵庫県豊岡市）に生まれた。
sen.e: He was born the first son of Sekimon SAKURAI, a jukan (an official under Confucianism) of the Izushi Domain, at the Igi district of Izushi town (present Toyooka City, Hyogo Prefecture).

sen.j: 8歳で藩校の弘道館に入門した。

sen.e: Later, he studied under scholars such as Shoken HOTTA, Kinryo YOSHINO, and Goga DOI and refined his education.

sen.j: 内務省地理局長時代には全国の測候所の創設を働きかけ、気象観測網の基礎を築いた。
sen.e: When working as the head of the Geography Bureau at the Ministry of Home Affairs, he strived to set up meteorological stations nationwide and laid the foundation of the weather observation network.

sen.j: その後、徳島県知事、山梨県知事一覧、台湾新竹知事、内務省神社局長を歴任、1902年（明治35年）に退官した。
sen.e: Afterwards, he held various posts in a row, such as the Governor of Tokushima Prefecture, the Governor of Yamanashi Prefecture, and the Governor of Shinchiku Prefecture of Taiwan, and retired from office in 1902.

Afterwards, he held various posts in a row, such as the Governor of Tokushima Prefecture, the Governor of Yamanashi Prefecture, and the Governor of Shinchiku Prefecture of Taiwan, and the chief of the Bureau of Shrines of the Ministry of Home Affairs, then retired from office in 1902.

sen.j: 退官後は出石に戻り、「校補但馬考」を著して但馬国の郷土史研究の基礎を築いたほか、教育振興などにつとめた。
sen.e: After retirement, he returned to Izushi, where he formed the foundation of studies on local history of the Tajima Province by writing "Revised Tajima Study" and contributed to the promotion of education.

After the retirement, he returned to Izushi, where he formed the foundation of studies on local history of the Tajima Province by writing 'Revised Tajima Study,' as well as contributed to the promotion of education.

sen.j: 気象台（東京気象台、現気象庁）の設置は、工部省により計画され、内務省 (日本)によって実現された。
sen.e: The introduction of a meteorological observatory (Tokyo Meteorological Observatory, present Japan Meteorological Agency) was proposed by the Kobusho (the Ministry of Industry) and achieved by the Ministry of Home Affairs.

The establishment of the meteorological observatory (Tokyo Meteorological Observatory, present Japan Meteorological Agency) was proposed by the Kobusho (the Ministry of Industry) and realized by the Ministry of Home Affairs (Japan).

sen.e: The establishment of the meteorological observatory (Tokyo Meteorological Observatory, present Japan Meteorological Agency) was proposed by the Kobusho (the Ministry of Industry) and realized by the Ministry of Home Affairs (Japan).

sen.j: その後、内務省地理局長に就任した桜井は気象観測網の整備を進める。
sen.e: Later, Sakurai, who was assigned to the head of the Geography Bureau at the Ministry of Home Affairs, pursued the establishment of the weather observation network.

sen.j: しかし、明治政府には国営で整備する余裕はなかった。
sen.e: The Meiji government, however, had no spare budget to establish the national network.

sen.j: このため、桜井は府県に測候所の創設を働きかけ、明治12年（1879年）1月1日、広島県が広島測候所（現広島地方気象台）を設置して気象観測を開始した。
sen.e: Sakurai, therefore, enticed prefectures to build a meteorological station, and Hiroshima Prefecture started weather observation by setting up the Hiroshima Meteorological Station (present Hiroshima Local Meteorological Observatory) on January 1, 1879.

sen.j: これを皮切りに、全国に測候所が設置され、気象観測網が整備されていった。
sen.e: Started by Hiroshima, meteorological stations were built nationwide, and the weather observation network gradually developed.

sen.j: 明治20年度には、内務省予算の削減のため、内務省が設置していた11の測候所も地方へ移管されている。
sen.e: In FY 1887, eleven meteorological stations that had been set up by the Ministry of Home Affairs were transferred to local governments due to reduction in the budget of the Ministry of Home Affairs.

sen.j: ちなみに、業務重複などによる非効率さや、地方財政状況による観測点維持の懸念などから、1939年（昭和14年）11月1日、全国の気象官署は国営化されている。
sen.e: Incidentally, due to inefficiency caused by a overlap between projects and concern over the maintenance of observation stations under restrained local budgets, nationwide meteorological offices were nationalized on November 1, 1939.

sen.j: 明治9年の府県統廃合の原案作成をしていた内務卿・大久保利通は、内務省高官で但馬国出身の桜井勉に、豊岡県と鳥取県の合併について意見を求めた。
sen.e: When Minister of Home Affairs Toshimichi OKUBO drew up a draft of prefectural consolidation in 1876, Okubo consulted with Tsutomu SAKURAI, who was a high-rank official at the Ministry of Home Affairs and came from Tajima Province, about the consolidation of Toyooka Prefecture and Tottori Prefecture.

When the Minister of Home Affairs Toshimichi OKUBO drew up a draft of prefectural reorganization in 1876, Okubo consulted with Tsutomu SAKURAI, who was a high-rank official at the Ministry of Home Affairs and came from Tajima Province, about the consolidation of Toyooka Prefecture and Tottori Prefecture.

sen.e: When the Minister of Home Affairs Toshimichi OKUBO drew up a draft of prefectural reorganization in 1876, Okubo consulted with Tsutomu SAKURAI, who was a high-rank official at the Ministry of Home Affairs and came from Tajima Province, about the consolidation of Toyooka Prefecture and Tottori Prefecture.

sen.j: 桜井勉は、歴史的背景からはもっともな案であるが、但馬と因幡国の間は山が険しく往来が不便であるため、鳥取県は島根県、豊岡県は飾磨県と合併させる方が適切であると進言した。
sen.e: Sakurai advised as follows: although Okubo's plan was authentic from a historical perspective, it would be better that Tottori Prefecture should be integrated with Shimane Prefecture while Toyooka Prefecture with Shikama Prefecture because transportation between Tajima Province and Inaba Province suffered inconvenience due to steep mountains.

sen.j: 物産が豊かな飾磨県を当時基盤の弱かった兵庫県と合併させることを考えていた大久保利通は、これに豊岡県を加えると大きくなりすぎるため難色を示した。
sen.e: As Toshimichi OKUBO was planning to consolidate Shikama Prefecture, which enjoyed rich productions, with Hyogo Prefecture, which had weak financial base at that time, he frowned at Sakurai's suggestion for the addition of Toyooka Prefecture to his Shikama consolidation plan because the scale of a new prefecture became too large.

As Toshimichi OKUBO was planning to consolidate Shikama Prefecture, which was enriched with its products, with Hyogo Prefecture, which had a weak financial base at that time, he frowned at Sakurai's suggestion for the addition of Toyooka Prefecture to his Shikama consolidation plan, because the scale of the new prefecture could become too large.

sen.j: このため豊岡県を二分し、丹後国および丹波国の天田郡を京都府、但馬および丹波の氷上郡、多紀郡を兵庫県に編入することを再提案した。
sen.e: Sakurai then suggested for dividing Toyooka Prefecture into two areas--Amata County, an area which had sit on Tango Province and Tanba Province; and Hikami County, an area which had sit on Tajima Province and Tanba Province--and proposed that Amata County should be integrated into Kyoto Prefecture while Hikami County into Hyogo Prefecture.

Sakurai then suggested the division of Toyooka Prefecture into two areas and its' incorporation; the Amata County, an area which had sat on Tango Province and Tanba Province to integrate to Kyoto Prefecture, and the Hikami and Taki Counties, which had sat on Tajima Province and Tanba Province to Hyogo Prefecture.

sen.j: この意見が取り入れられ、現在の京都府と兵庫県が誕生した。
sen.e: His second suggestion was accepted, and present Kyoto Prefecture and Hyogo Prefecture came into the world.
